citation.article-title: Saccharobacter fermentatus gen. nov., sp. nov., a new ethanol-producing bacterium.

p.s: Description of Saccharobacter fermentatus sp. nov.
Saccharobacter fermentatus (fer. men. ta' tus. M. L. adj. fermentatus, fermentative)
The morphological characteristics are the same as those described above for the genus.
Colonies on glucose-yeast extract agar are nonpigmented, opaque, milky white, smooth, and low convex with entire margins.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA is 63.5 ± 0.2 mol% (as determined by the thermal denaturation method) (6).

The following carbon sources are fermented after incubation at 30°C for 1 day: D-glucose, D-fructose, sucrose, maltose, D-xylose, L-sorbose, trehalose, L-arabinose, D-galactose, D-mannitol, esculin, L-rhamnose, melibiose, and starch.
Lactose is fermented after incubation for 9 days.
Dulcitol, myo-inositol, raffinose, and gluconate are not fermented after incubation for 9 days.
Malonate is used as a sole carbon source.
Ammonium sulfate, yeast extract, urea, phenylalanine, glutamine, and tryptone are used as sole nitrogen sources, but sodium glutamate is not.
The following enzyme activity tests are negative: hydrolysis of gelatin, H2S production on TSI medium, oxidase, urease, nitrate reduction, and Moeller tests for decarboxylase.
Catalase positive, β-galactosidase positive, and arginine dihydrolase positive (on day 4).
Tolerates 35% (wt/vol) glucose and 6% NaCl but not 40% (wt/vol) glucose or 8% NaCl.
The type strain is strain WVB8512, which is kept at the Wuhan Institute of Virology, Academia Sinica, Wuhan, People's Republic of China.
This culture is grown on glucose-peptone-yeast extract agar and is stored in lyophilized ampoules.
